title: Herbert A. Simon
summary: Herbert Alexander Simon (June 15, 1916 – February 9, 2001) was an American economist, computer scientist, political scientist and cognitive psychologist, whose primary research interest was decision-making within organizations and is best known for the theories of "bounded rationality" and "satisficing".[5] He received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 1978 and the Turing Award in computer science in 1975.[6][7] His research was noted for its interdisciplinary nature and spanned across the fields of cognitive science, computer science, public administration, management, and political science.[8] He was at Carnegie Mellon University for most of his career, from 1949 to 2001.[9]
